title: 2014 European Tour
text:
The 2014 European Tour was the sixth edition of the <a href="Race%20to%20Dubai">Race to Dubai</a> and the 43rd season of <a href="golf">golf</a> tournaments since the <a href="European%20Tour">European Tour</a> officially began in 1972.
Northern Ireland's <a href="Rory%20McIlroy">Rory McIlroy</a> won the Race to Dubai for the second time, having won two <a href="men%27s%20major%20golf%20championships">majors</a>, a <a href="World%20Golf%20Championships">WGC</a> and the European Tour's flagship event, the <a href="BMW%20PGA%20Championship">BMW PGA Championship</a>, during the season. He was also named <a href="European%20Tour%20Golfer%20of%20the%20Year">Golfer of the Year</a>. <a href="Brooks%20Koepka">Brooks Koepka</a> of the United States was the <a href="Sir%20Henry%20Cotton%20Rookie%20of%20the%20Year">Sir Henry Cotton Rookie of the Year</a>.
<a href="Miguel%20%C3%81ngel%20Jim%C3%A9nez">Miguel Ángel Jiménez</a> twice broke his own record as the oldest winner in the history of the European Tour as he defended the <a href="Hong%20Kong%20Open%20%28golf%29">Hong Kong Open</a> title in December and won the <a href="Open%20de%20Espa%C3%B1a">Open de España</a> the following May. With victory in his national open, he also became the tour's only winner over the age of 50.
Schedule.
The table below shows the 2014 European Tour schedule, which began with five events in late 2013. The schedule comprised 49 tournaments counting for the Race to Dubai, including the four <a href="Men%27s%20major%20golf%20championships">major championships</a> and four <a href="World%20Golf%20Championships">World Golf Championships</a>, and concluded with four Final Series events culminating at the <a href="DP%20World%20Tour%20Championship%2C%20Dubai">DP World Tour Championship, Dubai</a> at the end of November.
New tournaments for the 2014 season were the <a href="Made%20in%20Denmark">Made in Denmark</a>, <a href="D%2BD%20Real%20Czech%20Masters">D+D Real Czech Masters</a> tournaments and the <a href="EurAsia%20Cup">EurAsia Cup</a> team event between the Europe Tour and the <a href="Asian%20Tour">Asian Tour</a>. Lost from the schedule were the <a href="Avantha%20Masters">Avantha Masters</a> and the <a href="Johnnie%20Walker%20Championship%20at%20Gleneagles">Johnnie Walker Championship at Gleneagles</a>, with the venue hosting the <a href="2014%20Ryder%20Cup">2014 Ryder Cup</a>. In addition, the <a href="Ballantine%27s%20Championship">Ballantine's Championship</a> moved from South Korea to Singapore and was renamed as <a href="The%20Championship%20at%20Laguna%20National">The Championship at Laguna National</a>. A third new tournament, the <a href="NH%20Collection%20Open">NH Collection Open</a>, a dual-ranking event with the second-tier <a href="Challenge%20Tour">Challenge Tour</a>, was later added to the schedule.
Race to Dubai.
Since 2009, the European Tour's money list has been known as the "Race to Dubai". It is based on money earned during the season and is calculated in <a href="euro">euro</a>, with earnings from tournaments that award prize money in other currencies being converted at the exchange rate available the week of the event. The following table shows the final top-10 in the 2014 standings and includes the bonus pool and bonus points from the "Final Series" (earnings converted to points before the Final Series).
